div1.p: 424 W. Chelten Ave. Germantown, Philad Pa September 18 1906.

Your communication of date Brussels, July 23. 1906 mis-sent to the Congo Reform Association, finally reached me Aug. 17. while I was confined under a surgical operation in the Presbyterian Hospital of this city. I emerged only a few days go.
You give me your address both in Paris and Baltimore. I choose the latter address. And, though your letter leaves somewhat to be desired in the matter of courtesy, I reply to it.

When I landed in New York on the 7. of last June, I was, in half an hour, surrounded by half a dozen reporters. I did not, and do not know whom they represented, though tey doubtless told me. They asked me about the Kongo atrocities; and I answered freely, as I do every where. They got my statements somewhat disjointed, in intervals of the examination of my large lot of luggage by the Custom House officials. Naturally, they made some mistakes. I am not on a Lecture-Tour for the Congo Reform Association of the U.S. At that time, I did not know even of that Association's existence.
What I said to them wa that, in my missionary addresses among the Churches during my furlough, I should animal- vert on those atrocities.

I have not been in the Kongo Free State. There are 3 "Congos": the Kongo Free State, or Kongo Belge; the Kongo River; and the Kongo Français. What I said to them was that I had been 45 years in the Kongo-Français, a few hundred mils north of the Kongo river.

I am a missionary of the American Presbyterian Church (north) offices at 156 Fifth. Ave New York city One of my stations being Libreville, in the Gaboon river, exactly on the equator; Libreville being headquarter of the Colonial Government of the Kongo-Français until its authority was divided with Brazzaville on the Kongo.

It is quite possible that I am unkown unknown to the Free State officials. But, they could have heart of me had they inquired of Rev. Mr. Grenfell and other Baptist missionaries; of Rev. Messrs. Verner and Phipps of the Am. Presb. (south); and of the American Missionaries at Boma. Your officials would argue themselves unknown if they could not hear of me through the Captains of any of Elder Dempster line of steamers running as far south as the Gaboon and Kongo rivers. Or, from my friend Consul Sir Alfred Jones.

A few hours after I had told those reporters that story of the flogging to death of that young woman, one of them followe me to 156 Fifth. Ave, with his written version of it, and asked me to sign it as correct.

I did not know who he was nor whom he represented. It was substantially correct. A month later I was shown it in the "Journal-Exam". The preliminary and the final remarks are not mine, though they are true. The story itself is, excepting the two minor inaccuracies, viz that the white man did the flogging; and, that the flogging was continued on the second day. Indeed, I doubt whether these two points are inaccuracies. Practically the white man did do the flogging; it was done for him at the point of his pistol: one of his native would not hesitate to do the flogging himself if it was convenient for him. And, as to the second day's flogging, I have no doubt it also was done. He did as bad with that honey. People familiar with African insects know their abundan-
ce, their universality and their torture.

I heard this case talked of on the english steamers at the time. It was commonly known. That was 2 years ago. I can not recall the persons, captains and passengers, whom I overheard talking about it. Their version was one of the "portions" of the girl's body covered by the honey was her genitals. I have no doubt that it was so. For the stamementstatement was also made that the "service" in which she was engaged to this man was as his mistress. Of this also I have no doubt. In my long and intimate acquaintance with african conditions, I know that many of the white commercial foreign population have their native "Wives" more or less openly held. Some of them treat their young women kindly; some are cruel. I know of no service which young women render in the trading houses other than a sexual one.

I wish to repeat that I am not, and have not been, in any way, connected with the American Congo Reform Association, except that I heartily approve of its object and its work; a work for which my sympathy was early extended to Mr. E.D. Morel of Liverpool.
Very truly yours, (s) Robert Hamill Nassau
His Honor, J.G Whiteley, Consul General of the Congo Free State to the United States of America.
